captions.text:
Well, I wanted a triple-A game to come out
and it doesn&#39;t get much more triple-A than
this.

Spider-Man means Sony, it means Marvel, it
means Disney, it means they couldn&#39;t animate

Spider-Man scratching his arse until six teams
of lawyers had discussed it for a week.

You can practically smell the money coming
off this one.

So of course they&#39;re going to milk it til
its kidneys plop out.

I go to buy it, it goes &quot;Do you want the standard
edition for the usual only faintly extortionate

sixty bucks or the deluxe edition for the
obviously bullshit eighty?
You get a whole three more missions!&quot;
Oh okay.

So by &quot;deluxe edition&quot; what you meant was
&quot;intact edition.&quot;
&quot;Unbutchered edition.&quot;

&quot;Edition that wasn&#39;t picked apart on the surgeon&#39;s
table by Doctor Nickel and Doctor Dime.&quot;
You don&#39;t get this in films.

They don&#39;t bring the lights up halfway through
and say &quot;Could the silver ticket holders kindly

fuck off for twenty minutes so the gold ticket
holders can watch a few subplots.&quot;

Anyway, I went for the standard edition because
I wasn&#39;t going to let more of this dominate
my weekend than necessary.

Marvel&#39;s Spider-Man is of course a new sandbox
game about Spider-Man, a genre that has seen

one exemplar, Spider-Man 2 on the Gamecube,
and a whole load of Spider-Manure since then.
So let&#39;s get straight to the big question.

Is Disney&#39;s Marvel&#39;s Spider-Man a better Spider-Man
game than Spider-Man 2?
The answer is, ye-es.

And that incidentally was my entry for the
2018 &#39;most subtext in a single syllable&#39; competition.

It is, in the sense that Sony&#39;s Disney&#39;s Marvel&#39;s
Spider-Man does CONTAIN a better Spider-Man
game.

If you broke it down to component bits and
selectively reconstructed it you&#39;d have a
perfect Spider-Man game.

The problem is, the game also contains, every
other game that has ever existed in the history
of the world.
Most predominantly Batman: Arkham City.

And the advice I&#39;ve given to pretty much every
Spider-Man game in the last decade has been
&quot;Stop trying to be Batman!

Embrace the things that make you special,
Spider-Man!

You can&#39;t skulk in the shadows, you&#39;re dressed
like the top of a police car, for fuck&#39;s sake!&quot;

So while the webswinging in Sony&#39;s Disney&#39;s
Marvel&#39;s Stan Lee&#39;s Spider-Man is great, it

looks good and requires finesse, and there
are races and stunt challenges and boss fights

that make the most of it, we also have to
do the usual fucking stealthy base assaults.

And once again someone rips off the Arkham-style
predator mission without understanding the
ingredient that made them work: ESCALATION.

The enemies got twitchier and more scared
as you picked them off, the situation evolved.
If it doesn&#39;t it gets boring.
Isolate, pick off.
Isolate, pick off.

Whoops, no more isolated ones, DISTRACT, isolate,
pick off.

But what&#39;s really galling is that even if
I successfully pick them all off with no alerts

half the time the game just spawns more dudes
pre-alerted for your convenience and you&#39;re
forced to fight them.

I spent ten minutes going out of my way to
careful careful stealthy stealth the first

round of lads but apparently I might as well
have just blundered in here in a sombrero

with my knob out for all the good it - hang
on, why does it say &quot;WAVE 1&quot; at the top of
the screen?
Oh, you&#39;re just padding this out, now.
The combat&#39;s already somewhat annoying.

It&#39;s got nice variety and you can bestow a
smorgasbord of blatantly life-threatening

spinal injuries upon random goons, but I guess
they all got bitten by radioactive rolled-up

newspapers &#39;cos even basic thugs can knock
your health down rapidly and the Spider-Sense

effect that tells you when to dodge is wonky
as balls.

Sometimes it goes off when nothing&#39;s about
to hit you, at other times it goes off .1

seconds before a hitherto unannounced rocket
obliterates your spider-nads.

So the base assaults are a miserable chore,
frankly.
Oh well, at least it&#39;s still superhero stealth.

At least you&#39;re not some boring fuck crouched
behind a box throwing distraction objects

and getting instakilled the moment you get
spotted.
Ahem.

I don&#39;t like the sound of that cough you just
made, Marvel&#39;s Sony&#39;s Steve Ditko&#39;s Spider-Man.

&quot;Well, the thing is, we thought we could have
a few missions throughout the campaign where

you play as Spider-Man&#39;s normal human mates,
crouching behind boxes, throwing distraction
objects, and, er, the other thing.
You know, for variety.&quot;

So let me see if I&#39;ve got this straight, Insomniac
Games&#39; Disney&#39;s Spider-Man.

You&#39;re going to interrupt your high-octane
big balls web swinging free roam superhero

power fantasy for the sake of some mandatory
forced stealth sections playing as a mundane

fuck going on a chest high wall inspection
tour.

And you&#39;re doing this so that we DON&#39;T get
bored?

Yes, downtime is important for pacing, but
the downtime in a Spider-Man game is when

you blow off the missions for a bit to idly
challenge yourself to web swing all the way

across the map without losing speed or mentioning
that you&#39;re from New York.

Speaking of the campaign, the story takes
another cue from Batman Arkham Asylum, which
went &quot;You fucking know who Batman is.
Shut up, don&#39;t lie.

You know who the Joker is, you know who the
Riddler is.

Let&#39;s just get on with the fun and not piss
about with origin stories.&quot;

Marvel&#39;s Clive Barker&#39;s Spider-Man mostly
does that, it&#39;s 8 years into Spider-Man&#39;s

career, and there&#39;s a rather loose plot existing
mainly as an excuse for a villain showcase.

No offense, Spider-Man, but your villains
kinda suck.

Although it would be weird if you did take
offense to that.

There&#39;s only two kinds, the silly villains,
bank robbers with really obvious themes and

generic villain personalities so if you swapped
their powers around you couldn&#39;t tell the

fuckers apart, and the serious villains, who
are all former Peter Parker father figures
with Jekyll and Hyde issues.

Peter Parker really needs to learn to stop
latching onto older men, it never ends well.

The exception to the no origin stories rule
is Doctor Octopus.
He gets origin story for days.

There&#39;s like ninety million plot missions
where you just hang around the lab so Dr.

Octavius can drop another hint and make another
weird face to camera, until you&#39;re going &quot;FOR

FUCK&#39;S SAKE WE KNOW HE&#39;S GOING TO BE DOCTOR
OCTOPUS, STOP ARSING ABOUT AND BOLT SOME JAPANESE
RAPE TENTACLES TO THIS MOTHERFUCKER.&quot;

Marvel&#39;s Disney&#39;s Sony&#39;s Insomniac Games&#39;
Stan Lee&#39;s Steve Ditko&#39;s Giant-Sized Man Thing

achieves that wonderful quality of Spider-Man
2 in which it was just fun and not a little

zen to wile away the afternoon randomly swinging
through the streets, stumbling on collectibles
and little crimes to foil.

Which may ultimately be enough, but I feel
like saying it&#39;s a really good game is like

saying the Bible supports the ostracision
of homosexuals.

It&#39;s true, but only if you cherry pick bits
of it from the piles and piles of other stuff.

Webswinging becomes the spoonful of sugar
to help keep down the base assaults, the forced

stealth missions with other characters, the
weirdly elaborate science minigames where

you have to play Pipe Dream and do tile matching
puzzles, and which make me think that Octavius

went off the deep end because he was sick
of sitting around the lab playing Doctor Mario
all fucking day.

This sort of design is the result of seeking
the broadest possible audience, but I would

argue that there is still value in a refined
experience.

It&#39;s a bit unfair that triple-A games can
afford to just keep throwing bollocks at the
wall until some of it sticks.

Sticky bollocks are the last thing you want
when you&#39;re wearing spandex tights.
